ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom.
Live virtual discussion section
Also a live discussion section each week.
Live, virtual lecture with a weekly section
Live lecture and discussion.
There was an additional discussion section.
We had live virtual lectures to cover the course material along with virtual discussion sections to gain increased familiarity with the content.
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, virtual seminar/discussion section
With a weekly virtual discussion section
live virtual weekly discussion section
Weekly discussion section
sections
We also had a live, virtual discussion section
Live virtual lecture combined with small group virtual discussion section.
I attended the course with live-lectures and discussion sections
In addition to the live recorded virtual lecture, there were weekly 50-minute virtual discussion sections.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course explores ancient Pre-Socratic and some Post-Socratic philosophers and their works. Emphasis on Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle. Learned to read some complex philosophical texts and how to formulate philosophical arguments. Teaches you how to discuss the intangible and write compelling essays regarding it.

I learned how to carefully write a philosophy essay, including making a solid outline and giving solid analysis to back up my thesis. Also, I learned how to think more critically about the works of the ancient philosophers we read, particularly Plato and Aristotle. I feel like I have a really firm grasp on them and am really satisfied with how much I learned about their ideas.
How to make philosophical arguments, how to read philosophy critically, how to write a philosophy paper

I developed a basic understanding of ancient Greek philosophy, with special emphasis on philosophers like Plato, Aristotle, etc. I also learned how to write a philosophy paper and what makes a philosophy paper cohesive.
Brief intro to a lot of different philosophers.
I learned the main philosophical ideas of a wide range of ancient philosophers from the pre-Socratics to the Epicureans and Stoics

I learned about Plato, Aristotle, Epicurus, Lucretius and the presocratics in this course. I learned how to write a philosophy and critically analyze philosophical ideas in a somewhat rigorous way. I learned how ancient philosophers responded to one another and built upon each others ideas.

I learned how to reason better about philosophical texts and really appreciate the history behind philosophy. I also became a much better writer when it comes to crafting very careful analysis of complex arguments.

I learned a lot about the philosophical teachings of a wide variety of ancient philosophers. I also learned how to write a philosophy paper and how to effectively engage with and understand ancient writings.
I vastly improved my writing and communicating skills about advanced philosophical content.
A survey of ancient philosophers and their beliefs
I developed my reading skills and learned about how to analyze philosophical structures from the ground up.
analysis
We read and analyzed philosophical texts spanning from early Greek philosophy (pre-Socratic) to Epicureanism, Stoicism, and Sketpicism.

PHIL 125 teaches the basics of philosophy, from different styles of argumentation to the basic theories of various Greek thinkers. The course emphasizes the importance of analyzing these theories with respect to each other to develop a more critical lens to all forms of thought.

A solid understanding of ancient Greek thought and the practice of philosophy in general. Covered the Presocratics, Plato, Aristotle, etc. 

Most importantly I learned how to write philosophy essays. This part was challenging but worthwhile.

This course provides a brief overview of the ideas developed by early greek philosophers. Not much depth is provided, but a satisfying treatment nonetheless. 

Writing skills may improve depending on the quality of feedback you receive from TAs after each essay.
I now have a clearer image on Greek philosophers world-views and contributions.  I learned how to better organize my thoughts on paper.
A good introduction to the pre-Socratics, the works of Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, and Epicureanism.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor is very helpful and kind. TF's are super helpful as well. Readings can be interesting.
Weaknesses: Can become very burdensome along with other intensive classes. Must have a good writing background and some experience in philosophy to do super well, otherwise its very challenging material. Sometimes can feel like no matter how hard you're trying on the papers, it's to no avail.

Only strengths. Professor Inwood is amazing and genuinely made me want to get up and attend live lectures, even on zoom. He's super kind and so knowledgeable. Also, our TF Austen Hall was amazing. He made discussions very interesting and was super helpful in giving guidance towards me essays.

Strengths: Professor Inwood is an excellent lecturer, and the discussion sections were fruitful. The readings were very interesting. The prompts were thought-provoking, and the process of writing philosophy essays was rewarding
Weaknesses: None
The content and readings were very interesting, but the lectures sometimes lost my attention. I think in a classroom setting this style lecture would have been fine, but online it was a bit tedious.

Professor Inwood is so knowledgable and is an amazingly engaging lecturer. I thoroughly enjoyed listening to him, even though this class was super early for me with the time difference. My TA was also very good; she gave us a lot of support and was always available to help. Some weaknesses are that, for a WR credit, there are not a lot of ways to get real writing practice besides the actual papers. This is hard because you can't practice the writing in a low-stakes environment. Also, there are some weird and unclear guidelines on peer reviewing, TAs reading drafts, etc. that are inconsistent amongst TAs. If this course is a writing course, then I think that TAs ought to be much more willing to read drafts (my TA wasn't) and would allow people to peer review (which, for some of the time, it wasn't).
The weakness of the course is that we cover too much content in a short amount of time but I guess that can't be changed.

The strengths are definitely the papers, the topics were thought provoking and fun! Lecture was okay, mostly a run through of the assigned reading which was helpful because even if you read it is still hard to fully understand. Section was also good though honestly too short. The greatest strength was my TA, Moya, she really cares about our learning and put in a ton of working reading our drafts and then final drafts! The weakness was probably that there were one or two weeks with a lot of reading and some with barely any so perhaps a more even spread would have been nicer.

Professor Inwood is amazing. He really cares a lot about the subject and that makes the lectures fun. He does a great job giving an explanation of the texts during lecture along with extra information about the texts that is helpful or interesting. The grading scheme is very helpful -- the worst paper has the lowest percentage of the overall grade, the best has the highest, etc. -- as this helps provide some flexibility that encourages students to not be discouraged or worried about writing the first paper for the course -- the first assignment for any course is always worrisome. The grading on the papers is fair as well. No weaknesses.

This course's lectures were very beneficial to understanding and analyzing the readings; however, they often were just summaries. We covered a lot of philosophers, so we didn't go super in-depth on anyone besides Aristotle and Plato. The course didn't really emphasize thinking philosophically. It was also difficult getting accustomed to writing the papers. Regardless, Professor Inwood was an incredible instructor who was very knowledgeable about all of the ancient works we covered throughout the semester.
Good lectures; hard to parse through some of the readings and interpret them correctly

This course has very strong lectures and discussion sections. The discussion of the material was very high quality. However, I wish there was more emphasis on the importance of the ideas with regard to a historical lens.
weakness: too few assignments to stay very engaged; strengths: amazing professor and TAs!
The course was well-organized and the readings were interesting, but the topics near the end of the course (Stoicism and Skepticism) seemed a bit more rushed than previous topics.

The course contains very interesting content; however, some works, such has the Republic and Phaedo are covered so quickly it is difficult to get a real grasp of the work. I understand this is the pitfall of a survey course, but I would have preferred either more depth in some of these works or less reading in something like the Republic because it makes the work seem more confusing and transient than it really is.
The lectures were pretty dry and easy to zone out of. However, the reading was very manageable and the essays were fun to write. Excellent teaching fellows too.

As much as I like being able to go to lecture, take little to no notes, barely do the readings, and then read just enough to write the essays, I feel like I would be more engaged with the class if it included reading quizzes or concept tests. 

Also it would be great if we were actually taught *how* to write philosophy essays, especially since we are expected to know how to write proper philosophy essays from the beginning and are graded accordingly. We spent maybe one discussion section going over how to write intro paragraphs and that was it! Everything else about how to write must be extrapolated from minimal feedback on papers.
The course was well facilitated and all the teaching staff was very helpful

This course's strengths definitely were the lectures that Professor Inwood provided discussing the readings. After sometimes being puzzled by the readings, Professor Inwood did a good job of clearing up our questions and giving summaries and explanations that cemented our learning.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual is very hard in general. It is difficult to make something like philosophy interesting over a computer screen compared to in person.
A really attentive TF helped make discussions on zoom function smoothly.
I don't think much could be improved in this regard
This course moved well to the virtual environment. The lectures were still excellent, and the sections involved lots of engagement.
The discussion sections worked out well for the most part since people engaged with the material.

Lecture was still very engaging and I always felt very free to ask questions whenever they came up. In fact, since we have a zoom chat we could just type them in the chat and the professor could answer them after he finished his thought which was super useful. Something that was weak was sections are difficult to pull off especially with such short time but its hard to complain when I think they are the best they can be.

The short discussion posts was very helpful in encouraging participation and provided a nice review of that days material. This would be helpful even in in-person courses. Lectures and sections were conducted very well.
The virtual lectures being recorded was very helpful.
Thought the lectures and discussion sections all worked fine on Zoom; enjoyed that lectures were recorded as well if you wanted to go back to them
I felt that the course adapted quite well to the pandemic.
The lecture and discussion sections translated well into the virtual setting.
I loved professor Inwood's live lectures and our discussion section was very active and "normal." No major complaints.
I think the class was very well organized for the online experience

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: take it if you plan on taking more classes in the phil dept. You need the foundation.
Only if required for your major. I wanted to take a fun philosophy class, and this was not it.
Yes! Fantastic course, especially if you are interested in Plato and Aristotle! You really see the similarities and huge differences between their schools of thought.
if you are at all interested in studying philosophy at Yale, and do not want to jump into a more challenging course, you should take this one.

Yes, I would actually recommend this class to people regardless of major because I think it gives you a great background of ancient Greek philosophy. This course focuses more on breadth than depth, which is good in an introduction level course. The papers increase in difficulty, which is good because it challenges you. I will say that this course might be a tad difficult for people who have never written philoosphy papers before because there isn't the best support for learning how to write papers.
I would only if the student was willing to put in the work to do the readings and actually engage with the material.
Absolutely. loved this class, Brad, and my TA
yes

Yes a hundred times!!! I really loved this course and it helped me formalize a lot of my own philosophical ideas. At first, I was thrown off by the presocratics but I over time stuff started coming together and it became really fun to understand and analyze. The papers are also fun to write even as a STEM major who has only taken one writing credit two years ago. My TA was super supportive and gave us plenty of resources so that I really knew how to write a philosophy paper my first time. The material is also super interesting and challenges you to think deeper about politics and life.

Absolutely! Although the material is, well, ancient, the course is super interesting and will make you a better thinker. It really makes you appreciate philosophy and there will be some philosopher's argument in the course that you will probably find super interesting to learn about. Professor Inwood is great and the lectures provide useful information beyond the texts. Some of the texts are very intriguing to read and all the texts will at least make you think.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is very interested in having an overview of ancient philosophers or who wants to learn how to write a philosophy paper. If you are a philosophy major, definitely take this course. I personally had a wonderful experience with my TF Austen Hall, and I feel like your TF contributes greatly to your time in the class. If you desire to see the basis of the evolution of Western Thought take this course, but be aware that many of the teachings and beliefs aren't really applicable in contemporary times.
Yes, even though I didn't go great in the class, I enjoyed the lectures and the topics they covered
I would recommend this course to any student interested in learning the basics about the foundation of Western philosophy.
Yes, this is a very interesting and valuable survey course that covers a vast range of ancient Greek philosophy. The professor was really engaging and I learned a lot from the selected readings.

Absolutely! Take PHIL 125 if you like philosophy, hate philosophy, or indifferent. Even if you dislike the thinkers and the content, you will love being able to share your thoughts on the theories in engaging and fun papers.
Yes! If you are interested in philosophy or want to learn how to write airtight essays, Id definitely recommend it.
This course is a great introductory course to philosophy. It is an enjoyable way to learn and discuss about Greek philosophers

Yes, but only if they only already had an interest in the material. Professor Inwood has a great grasp of the material and his lectures are interesting if you have a sincere interest in what he's talking about
